This is actually a common threading problem that has nothing to do with
JUnit. I wrote a java program that runs DOS commands that has the same
problem. What you need to do  is have your test run in a worker thread,
and then join it to a control thread that will timeout the worker thread
if it takes too long:

	Thread t = new Thread( getWorkerRunnable() );
	t.start();
	try{ t.join( 10000 ); }
	catch(InterruptedException e){
		if(DEBUG) System.out.println(debugStr + e.toString());
		e.printStackTrace();
	}

This code joins the workerThread to the main Execution thread ( every
java program has a main execution thread ) and times out after 10
seconds. Atfter the catch you can kill the worker Thread
